RTS1 Film Lab Handbook

Complete documentation of Edition 1: September 6-10, 2024, Namibia

Return to the Source: Pan-African Film Lab & Residency Programme

Dates: September 6-10, 2024

Venue: Otjisazu Guest Farm, Ovitoto & Goethe-Institut Namibia, Windhoek

Funded by: Mastercard Enablement Programme & Goethe-Institut Namibia

Supported by: Mucii Pictures & Old Location Films

Programme Overview

"It is with great pleasure that we welcome you to this groundbreaking initiative designed to connect history, cinema, and community through the powerful medium of film. Over the next five days, we will embark on a journey that delves deep into Namibia's rich yet traumatic past, exploring its colonial history and its enduring impact on contemporary life."

— Perivi Katjavivi & Fibby Kioria, Co-Founders

Return to the Source is not so much about learning the technical aspects of filmmaking as it is about using film as a tool to exorcise trauma, to reclaim embodied histories, and to confront colonial ghosts that still linger in our societies.

Programme Highlights

  • 12 filmmakers from 4 countries (50% women, 75% first-time lab attendees)
  • 3 genocide sites reclaimed as living sets with community permission
  • Embedded psychological support throughout the programme
  • Zero pitch decks, three collective short films completed
  • €67k in alumni grants secured post-programme
  • N$18,000 in local procurement supporting community economy

Programme Participants

Twelve talented filmmakers from across Africa participated in Edition 1, representing Tanzania, Ethiopia, Kenya, and Namibia. The cohort included established filmmakers, emerging voices, and community storytellers.

Explore Detailed Participant Profiles

For comprehensive biographies, filmographies, and participant stories:

View All Participants →

Perivi Katjavivi

Lead Facilitator & Visionary Filmmaker

Director of "Under the Hanging Tree" (Namibia's first Oscar submission). PhD candidate researching colonial memory sites.

Fibby Kioria

Program Director & Strategic Producer

Founder of Mucii Pictures. Co-founder East African Screen Collective. Extensive experience in Pan-African training initiatives.

Dr. Nashilongweshipwe Mushaandja

Theoretical Architect

Performance scholar at University of Namibia. Specializes in African performance archives and public cultures of social movements.

Khalid Shamis

Documentary Expert

Director of Rough Cut Lab Africa. Doctoral fellow researching African documentary storytelling.

Programme Schedule

The five-day programme combined intensive filmmaking training, historical site visits, community engagement, and collaborative film production. Each day built upon the previous, creating a comprehensive learning experience.

Day 1: Friday, September 6 - Introduction & Memory Sites

8:00 AM - 9:00 AM: Breakfast
9:00 AM - 10:00 AM: Welcome Address and introductions by Perivi Katjavivi
10:00 AM - 1:00 PM: Site Visit: Historical Exploration at Ovitoto with Guided Oral History
1:00 PM - 2:00 PM: Lunch Break
2:00 PM - 3:00 PM: Incorporating Archives into Film and Research (Dr. Mushaandja)
3:30 PM - 6:00 PM: Site Visit: Historical Explorations at Otjisazu
6:00 PM - 7:00 PM: Dinner
7:00 PM - 9:30 PM: Outdoor Screening: "A Story of Bones" with Q&A

Day 2: Saturday, September 7 - African Cinema and Historical Contexts

8:00 AM - 9:00 AM: Breakfast
9:00 AM - 10:30 AM: Introduction to African Film Genres and Alternative Epistemologies
10:30 AM - 11:30 AM: Masterclass: Film Screening "If Objects Could Speak" by Saitabao Kaiyare
11:30 AM - 1:00 PM: Masterclass: Shooting and Editing on Smartphones
1:00 PM - 2:00 PM: Lunch Break
2:00 PM - 3:30 PM: Masterclass: Field Recording Sound for Film
6:00 PM - 7:00 PM: Dinner
7:00 PM - 8:30 PM: Outdoor Screening: "Under the Hanging Tree"

Day 3: Sunday, September 8 - Shooting with the Local Community

8:00 AM - 9:00 AM: Breakfast
9:00 AM - 1:00 PM: Filming Session: Students film sites of colonial atrocities
1:00 PM - 2:00 PM: Lunch Break
2:00 PM - 3:00 PM: Special Address: German colonial history debates
3:00 PM - 4:00 PM: Master Class: Making "Under the Hanging Tree"
6:00 PM - 7:00 PM: Dinner
7:00 PM - 9:30 PM: Outdoor Screening: "Das Leere Grab" by Cece Mlay

Day 4: Monday, September 9 - Theoretical Discussions

8:00 AM - 9:00 AM: Breakfast
9:00 AM - 9:30 AM: Reflection and Feedback Session
9:30 AM - 11:00 AM: Interactive Panel: "Custodians of Memory?"
11:00 AM - 12:00 PM: Master Class: Making "Das leere Grab"
12:00 PM - 1:00 PM: Lunch Break
1:00 PM - 4:00 PM: Group Filming Activity with local community members
4:00 PM - 4:30 PM: Tea Break
4:30 PM - 6:00 PM: Editing Session (Khalid Shamis)

Day 5: Tuesday, September 10 - Screenings and Reflections

8:00 AM - 9:00 AM: Breakfast
9:00 AM - 1:00 PM: Final Editing Session (Perivi Katjavivi)
1:00 PM - 2:00 PM: Lunch Break
2:00 PM - 4:00 PM: Final Film Project Presentations
4:00 PM - 5:00 PM: Closing Remarks and Departures

Programme Impact & Outcomes

Edition 1 created measurable impact across multiple dimensions, from individual filmmaker development to community transformation and continental knowledge exchange.

Key Achievements

12 Filmmakers Trained
From 4 countries, 50% women, 75% first-time lab attendees
3 Films Completed
Zero pitch decks, three collective short films
€67k Grants Secured
Alumni funding for continued work
Community Impact
N$18,000 local procurement, 4 youth positions
